column2: AUTOMATED QUALITY MONITORING FOR CALL CENTERS USING SPEECH AND NLP
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest page-top headchar-capital

column2: TECHNOLOGIES
column3: page=0 xpos=4 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: G. Zweig, O. Siohan, G. Saon, B. Ramabhadran, D. Povey, L. Mangu and B. Kingsbury
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=0 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: ABSTRACT
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital above-double-space above-line-space

column2: This paper describes an automated system for assigning qual-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: ity scores to recorded call center conversations. The system com-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: bines speech recognition, pattern matching, and maximum entropy
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: classification to rank calls according to their measured quality.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Calls at both ends of the spectrum are flagged as “interesting” and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: made available for further human monitoring. In this process, the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: ASR transcript is used to answer a set of standard quality control
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: questions such as “did the agent use courteous words and phrases,”
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and to generate a question-based score. This is interpolated with
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the probability of a call being “bad,” as determined by maximum
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: entropy operating on a set of ASR-derived features such as “max-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: imum silence length” and the occurrence of selected n-gram word
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: sequences. The system is trained on a set of calls with associated
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: manual evaluation forms. We present precision and recall results
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: from IBM’s North American Help Desk indicating that for a given
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: amount of listening effort, this system triples the number of bad
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: calls that are identified, over the current policy of randomly sam-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: pling calls. The application that will be demonstrated is a research
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: prototype that was built in conjunction with IBM’s North Ameri-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: can call centers.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1. INTRODUCTION
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=4 left-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Every day, tens of millions of help-desk calls are recorded at call
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: centers around the world. As part of a typical call center operation
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a random sample of these calls is normally re-played to human
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: monitors who score the calls with respect to a variety of quality
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: related questions, e.g.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: • Was the account successfully identified by the agent?
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: • Did the agent request error codes/messages to help deter-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-space itemization tailchar-hiphen

column2: mine the problem?
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: • Was the problem resolved?
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent right-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: • Did the agent maintain appropriate tone, pitch, volume and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-space itemization

column2: pace?
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: This process suffers from a number of important problems: first,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: the monitoring at least doubles the cost of each call (first an opera-
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tor is paid to take it, then a monitor to evaluate it). This causes the
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: second problem, which is that therefore only a very small sample
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: of calls, e.g. a fraction of a percent, is typically evaluated. The
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: third problem arises from the fact that most calls are ordinary and
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: uninteresting; with random sampling, the human monitors spend
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: most of their time listening to uninteresting calls.
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: This work describes an automated quality-monitoring system
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: that addresses these problems. Automatic speech recognition is
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: used to transcribe 100% of the calls coming in to a call center,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: and default quality scores are assigned based on features such as
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=0 xpos=4 ypos=9 left-column left-indent right-over font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only column-bottom

column2: key-words, key-phrases, the number and type of hesitations, and
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified column-top headchar-lower

column2: the average silence durations. The default score is used to rank
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the calls from worst-to-best, and this sorted list is made available
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to the human evaluators, who can thus spend their time listening
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: only to calls for which there is some a-priori reason to expect that
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: there is something interesting.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The automatic quality-monitoring problem is interesting in
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: part because of the variability in how hard it is to answer the ques-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions. Some questions, for example, “Did the agent use courteous
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: words and phrases?” are relatively straightforward to answer by
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: looking for key words and phrases. Others, however, require es-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: sentially human-level knowledge to answer; for example one com-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: pany’s monitors are asked to answer the question “Did the agent
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: take ownership of the problem?” Our work focuses on calls from
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: IBM’s North American call centers, where there is a set of 31 ques-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions that are used to evaluate call-quality. Because of the high de-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: gree of variability found in these calls, we have investigated two
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: approaches:
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-line-space

column2: 1. Use a partial score based only on the subset of questions
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space itemization

column2: that can be reliably answered.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: 2. Use a maximum entropy classifier to map directly from
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-space itemization

column2: ASR-generated features to the probability that a call is bad
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent indented-line headchar-capital

column2: (defined as belonging to the bottom 20% of calls).
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: We have found that both approaches are workable, and we present
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: final results based on an interpolation between the two scores.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: These results indicate that for a fixed amount of listening effort,
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: the number of bad calls that are identified approximately triples
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: with our call-ranking approach. Surprisingly, while there has been
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: significant previous scholarly research in automated call-routing
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and classification in the call center , e.g. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], there has
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: been much less in automated quality monitoring per se.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2. ASR FOR CALL CENTER TRANSCRIPTION
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.1. Data
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The speech recognition systems were trained on approximately
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: 300 hours of 6kHz, mono audio data collected at one of the IBM
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: call centers located in Raleigh, NC. The audio was manually tran-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: scribed and speaker turns were explicitly marked in the word tran-
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: scriptions but not the corresponding times. In order to detect
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: speaker changes in the training data, we did a forced-alignment of
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the data and chopped it at speaker boundaries. The test set consists
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: of 50 calls with 113 speakers totaling about 3 hours of speech.
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.2. Speaker Independent System
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The raw acoustic features used for segmentation and recognition
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: are perceptual linear prediction (PLP) features. The features are
column3: page=0 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower column-bottom above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Proceedings of the Human Language Technology Conference of the NAACL, Companion Volume, pages 292–295,
column3: page=0 xpos=0 ypos=9 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-larger column-top line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: New York City, June 2006.  2006 c Association for Computational Linguistics
column3: page=0 xpos=1 ypos=9 single-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail year headchar-capital page-bottom

column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=-1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent box page-top table-area above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Table 1. ASR results depending on segmentation/clustering and
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space string-table headchar-capital

column2: adaptation type.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Table 2__
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent box indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space table-area above-double-space above-line-space

column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space string-table headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: mean-normalized 40-dimensional LDA+MLLT features. The SI
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: acoustic model consists of 50K Gaussians trained with MPE and
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: uses a quinphone cross-word acoustic context. The techniques are
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the same as those described in [6].
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.3. Incremental Speaker Adaptation
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: In the context of speaker-adaptive training, we use two forms
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: of feature-space normalization: vocal tract length normalization
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: (VTLN) and feature-space MLLR (fMLLR, also known as con-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-hiphen

column2: strained MLLR) to produce canonical acoustic models in which
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: some of the non-linguistic sources of speech variability have been
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: reduced. To this canonical feature space, we then apply a discrim-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: inatively trained transform called fMPE [7]. The speaker adapted
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: recognition model is trained in this resulting feature space using
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: MPE.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period

column2: We distinguish between two forms of adaptation: off-line and
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: incremental adaptation. For the former, the transformations are
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: computed per conversation-side using the full output of a speaker
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: independent system. For the latter, the transformations are updated
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: incrementally using the decoded output of the speaker adapted sys-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tem up to the current time. The speaker adaptive transforms are
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: then applied to the future sentences. The advantage of incremental
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: adaptation is that it only requires a single decoding pass (as op-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: posed to two passes for off-line adaptation) resulting in a decoding
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: process which is twice as fast. In Table 1, we compare the per-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: formance of the two approaches. Most of the gain of full offline
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: adaptation is retained in the incremental version.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 2.3.1. Segmentation and Speaker Clustering
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: We use an HMM-based segmentation procedure for segmenting
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: the audio into speech and non-speech prior to decoding. The rea-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: son is that we want to eliminate the non-speech segments in order
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to reduce the computational load during recognition. The speech
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: segments are clustered together in order to identify segments com-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ing from the same speaker which is crucial for speaker adaptation.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The clustering is done via k-means, each segment being modeled
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: by a single diagonal covariance Gaussian. The metric is given by
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the symmetric K-L divergence between two Gaussians. The im-
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: pact of the automatic segmentation and clustering on the error rate
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: is indicated in Table 1.
column3: page=1 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=1 xpos=4 ypos=9 left-column left-indent right-over font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only column-bottom

column3: page=1 xpos=6 ypos=-1 right-column centered left-indent right-indent box column-top table-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3. CALL RANKING
column3: page=1 xpos=6 ypos=1 right-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3.1. Question Answering
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: This section presents automated techniques for evaluating call
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: quality. These techniques were developed using a train-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ing/development set of 676 calls with associated manually gen-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: erated quality evaluations. The test set consists of 195 calls.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: The quality of the service provided by the help-desk represen-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tatives is commonly assessed by having human monitors listen to
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: a random sample of the calls and then fill in evaluation forms. The
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: form for IBM’s North American Help Desk contains 31 questions.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: A subset of the questions can be answered easily using automatic
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: methods, among those the ones that check that the agent followed
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the guidelines e.g.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: • Did the agent follow the appropriate closing script?
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: • Did the agent identify herself to the customer?
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent right-indent font-largest aligned-line shorter-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: But some of the questions require human-level knowledge of the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital

column2: world to answer, e.g.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: • Did the agent ask pertinent questions to gain clarity of the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column left-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-space itemization

column2: problem?
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-line-space

column2: • Were all available resources used to solve the problem?
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column left-indent right-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: We were able to answer 21 out of the 31 questions using pat-
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: tern matching techniques. For example, if the question is “Did
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the agent follow the appropriate closing script?”, we search for
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: “THANK YOU FOR CALLING”, “ANYTHING ELSE” and
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: “SERVICE REQUEST”. Any of these is a good partial match for
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line

column2: the full script, “Thank you for calling, is there anything else I can
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: help you with before closing this service request?” Based on the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: answer to each of the 21 questions, we compute a score for each
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: call and use it to rank them. We label a call in the test set as being
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: bad/good if it has been placed in the bottom/top 20% by human
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: evaluators. We report the accuracy of our scoring system on the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: test set by computing the number of bad calls that occur in the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: bottom 20% of our sorted list and the number of good calls found
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: in the top 20% of our list. The accuracy numbers can be found in
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: Table 2.
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail string-table headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 3.2. Maximum Entropy Ranking
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Another alternative for scoring calls is to find arbitrary features in
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: the speech recognition output that correlate with the outcome of a
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: call being in the bottom 20% or not. The goal is to estimate the
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: probability of a call being bad based on features extracted from
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the automatic transcription. To achieve this we build a maximum
column3: page=1 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower page-bottom

column2: __Figure 1__
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=-4 left-column left-indent right-indent box page-top figure-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Fig. 1. Display of selected calls.
column3: page=2 xpos=1 ypos=0 left-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: entropy based system which is trained on a set of calls with asso-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ciated transcriptions and manual evaluations. The following equa-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tion is used to determine the score of a call C using a set of N
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column centered right-indent font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: predefined features:
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-colon above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 1 <sup>N</sup>
column3: page=2 xpos=2 ypos=1 left-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space numbered-heading1

column2: P (class/C) = exp( X λ i f i (class, C)) (1)
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=1 left-column left-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: Z <sub>i=1</sub>
column3: page=2 xpos=1 ypos=1 left-column centered left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line shorter-tail headchar-capital above-double-space above-line-space

column2: where class ∈ {bad, not − bad}, Z is a normalizing factor, f i ()
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified font-largest hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: are indicator functions and {λ i } <sub>{i=1,N</sub> } are the parameters of the
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: model estimated via iterative scaling [8].
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Due to the fact that our training set contained under 700 calls,
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-comma

column2: we used a hand-guided method for defining features. Specifi-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: cally, we generated a list of VIP phrases as candidate features,
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-comma

column2: e.g. “THANK YOU FOR CALLING”, and “HELP YOU”. We
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: also created a pool of generic ASR features, e.g. “number of hes-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: itations”, “total silence duration”, and “longest silence duration”.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: A decision tree was then used to select the most relevant features
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: and the threshold associated with each feature. The final set of fea-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tures contained 5 generic features and 25 VIP phrases. If we take a
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: look at the weights learned for different features, we can see that if
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: a call has many hesitations and long silences then most likely the
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line itemization headchar-lower

column2: call is bad.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: We use P (bad|C) as shown in Equation 1 to rank all the calls.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column left-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-period

column2: Table 3 shows the accuracy of this system for the bottom and top
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified hanged-line string-table headchar-capital

column2: 20% of the test calls.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail tailchar-period

column2: At this point we have two scoring mechanisms for each call:
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail headchar-capital tailchar-colon

column2: one that relies on answering a fixed number of evaluation ques-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tions and a more global one that looks across the entire call for
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: hints. These two scores are both between 0 and 1, and therefore
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: can be interpolated to generate one unique score. After optimizing
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the interpolation weights on a held-out set we obtained a slightly
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: higher weight (0.6) for the maximum entropy model. It can be
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: seen in Table 4 that the accuracy of the combined system is greater
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: that the accuracy of each individual system, suggesting the com-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: plementarity of the two initial systems.
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4. END-TO-END SYSTEM PERFORMANCE
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.1. Application
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column right-indent hanged-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: This section describes the user interface of the automated quality
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: monitoring application. As explained in Section 1, the evalua-
column3: page=2 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space
page=2 xpos=4 ypos=9 left-column left-indent right-over font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space numeric-only column-bottom

column2: __Figure 2__
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=-4 right-column left-indent right-indent box column-top figure-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Fig. 2. Interface to listen to audio and update the evaluation form.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: tor scores calls with respect to a set of quality-related questions
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified aligned-line line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: after listening to the calls. To aid this process, the user interface
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=0 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: provides an efficient mechanism for the human evaluator to select
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: calls, e.g.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • All calls from a specific agent sorted by score
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column left-indent right-indent font-largest indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: • The top 20% or the bottom 20% of the calls from a specific
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column left-indent font-largest aligned-line longer-tail line-space itemization

column2: agent ranked by score
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=1 right-column left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: • The top 20% or the bottom 20% of all calls from all agents
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column left-indent font-largest hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space itemization above-double-space above-line-space

column2: The automated quality monitoring user interface is a J2EE web
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified hanged-line line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: application that is supported by back-end databases and content
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: management systems <sup>1</sup> The displayed list of calls provides a link
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=2 right-column full-justified font-largest aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: to the audio, the automatically filled evaluation form, the overall
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: score for this call, the agent’s name, server location, call id, date
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and duration of the call (see Figure 1). This interface now gives
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the agent the ability to listen to interesting calls and update the
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: answers in the evaluation form if necessary (audio and evaluation
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=3 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: form illustrated in 2). In addition, this interface provides the eval-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: uator with the ability to view summary statistics (average score)
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and additional information about the quality of the calls. The over-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: all system is designed to automatically download calls from mul-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: tiple locations on a daily-basis, transcribe and index them, thereby
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=4 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: making them available to the supervisors for monitoring. Calls
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: spanning a month are available at any given time for monitoring
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: purposes.
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.2. Precision and Recall
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=5 right-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space above-double-space above-line-space

column2: This section presents precision and recall numbers for the
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: identification of “bad” calls. The test set consists of 195 calls that
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified font-largest hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: were manually evaluated by call center personnel. Based on these
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: manual scores, the calls were ordered by quality, and the bottom
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=6 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: 20% were deemed to be “bad.” To retrieve calls for monitoring,
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line tailchar-comma

column2: we sort the calls based on the automatically assigned quality score
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: and return the worst. In our summary figures, precision and recall
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: are plotted as a function of the number of calls that are selected
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: for monitoring. This is important because in reality only a small
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=7 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: number of calls can receive human attention. Precision is the ratio
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower above-double-space above-line-space

column2: <sup>1</sup> In our case, the backend consists of DB2 and IBM’s Websphere Infor-
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column left-indent font-larger indented-line line-double-space line-space headchar-super tailchar-hiphen

column2: mation Integrator for Content and the application is hosted on Websphere
column3: page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column full-justified font-smallest hanged-line headchar-lower
page=2 xpos=5 ypos=8 right-column right-indent font-smallest aligned-line shorter-tail page-bottom

column2: __Figure 3__
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=-3 left-column left-indent right-indent box page-top figure-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Fig. 3. Precision for the bottom 20% of the calls as a function of
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital

column2: the number of calls retrieved.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-double-space above-line-space

column2: __Figure 4__
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=0 left-column centered left-indent right-indent box indented-line longer-tail line-double-space line-space figure-area above-double-space above-line-space

column2: Fig. 4. Recall for the bottom 20% of the calls.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=2 left-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line shorter-tail line-double-space line-space headchar-capital tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: of bad calls retrieved to the total number of calls monitored, and
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space headchar-lower

column2: recall is the ratio of the number of bad calls retrieved to the total
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: number of bad calls in the test set. Three curves are shown in each
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: plot: the actually observed performance, performance of random
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=3 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: selection, and oracle or ideal performance. Oracle performance
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: shows what would happen if a perfect automatic ordering of the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: calls was achieved.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Figure 3 shows precision performance. We see that in the
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail string-figure headchar-capital

column2: monitoring regime where only a small fraction of the calls are
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=4 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: monitored, we achieve over 60% precision. (Further, if 20% of
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: the calls are monitored, we still attain over 40% precision.)
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower

column2: Figure 4 shows the recall performance. In the regime of low-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column left-indent indented-line longer-tail string-figure headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: volume monitoring, the recall is midway between what could be
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower

column2: achieved with an oracle, and the performance of random-selection.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: Figure 5 shows the ratio of the number of bad calls found with
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=5 left-column left-indent indented-line string-figure headchar-capital

column2: our automated ranking to the number found with random selection.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified hanged-line headchar-lower tailchar-period

column2: This indicates that in the low-monitoring regime, our automated
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-capital

column2: technique triples efficiency.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-blank-line above-double-space above-line-space

column2: 4.3. Human vs. Computer Rankings
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=6 left-column right-indent aligned-line longer-tail line-blank-line line-double-space line-space

column2: As a final measure of performance, in Figure 6 we present a
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line longer-tail headchar-capital

column2: scatterplot comparing human to computer rankings. We do not
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: have calls that are scored by two humans, so we cannot present a
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: human-human scatterplot for comparison.
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=7 left-column right-indent aligned-line shorter-tail headchar-lower tailchar-period above-line-space

column2: 5. CONCLUSION
column3: page=3 xpos=1 ypos=7 left-column centered left-indent right-indent indented-line longer-tail line-space itemization above-line-space

column2: This paper has presented an automated system for quality moni-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified hanged-line longer-tail line-space headchar-capital tailchar-hiphen

column2: toring in the call center. We propose a combination of maximum-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: entropy classification based on ASR-derived features, and question
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower

column2: answering based on simple pattern-matching. The system can ei-
column3: page=3 xpos=0 ypos=8 left-column full-justified aligned-line headchar-lower tailchar-hiphen

column2: ther be used to replace human monitors, or to make them more
